description: Brief review of High School calculus, applications of integrals, transcendental functions, methods of integration, infinite series, Taylor's theorem. Use of symbolic manipulation and graphics software in calculus.
name: CALCULUS I

values.comments:
MATH104 is the first calculus class in a four-part sequence, considered roughly equivalent to AP Calculus BC. After a quick review of limits, derivatives, basic integrals and u-substitution, the first half of the course teaches further techniques and applications of integration. The second part of the course centers on infinite sequences and series, followed by a brief introduction to differential equations.


Many students echoed that Professor van Erp was “one of the best math teachers” they’ve ever had. They praised his “straightforward,” “structured,” and “accessible” teaching methods, which made some of “the most complex parts of 104 seem simple and orderly.” Professor van Erp was very accessible out of class during office hours. The only complaint out of twenty reviews was that “he missed several lectures, and was out of town for the last week before the final.” Some students would have also preferred more theory taught in lectures. One person wrote, “the class was a great disappointment to me since there is no understanding of the mechanisms and only the use of a tool box.”

While most learned a lot from the course, some reviewers (with less strong math backgrounds) thought that the course was too fast-paced. Homework, midterms and a final determined a student’s final grade. Some students disliked the multiple-choice format on exams, “when a small error costs you 10% of your grade.” One student added, “I feel as though the grades in this class do not reflect the amount of effort the students put into this course.” Still, students strongly preferred this section of MATH104 over the other sections.

MATH104 fulfills basic requirements in all four undergraduate schools. The textbook used is Calculus by Stewart, 6th Edition.

MATH104 is the first calculus class in a four-part sequence, considered roughly equivalent to AP Calculus BC. After a quick review of limits, derivatives, basic integrals and u-substitution, the first half of the course teaches further techniques and applications of integration. The second part of the course centers on infinite sequences and series, followed by a brief introduction to differential equations.


Students went so far as to call this section “a very unfortunate experience,” “one of the worst decisions of my life,” and even “painfully, soul-suckingly awful.” Students thought that there was a “ridiculous amount of homework” and that the course was “extremely difficult.” Exams were not tailored to the material to be tested. One called it “needlessly dense,” targeted more towards math majors rather than the usual crowd of students taking the class to fulfill requirements.

While begrudging the fact that Professor Shaneson must be a “brilliant mathematician” to have tenure, many students verbosely and vehemently declared him the “worst professor I have ever had at Penn.” Instead of introducing a concept from the basics, Professor Shaneson started with a difficult, long-winded problem. He would move too quickly and skip steps, finishing material far in advance of the syllabus, and would then “trail off into another subject in the middle of the class.” Many wrote that they learned the material much better from the textbook or from the TA. On the other hand, some called him “entertaining,” and helpful in “one-on-one” interactions.

MATH104 fulfills basic requirements in all four undergraduate schools. The textbook used is Calculus by Stewart, 6th Edition.

MATH104 is the first calculus class in a four-part sequence, considered roughly equivalent to AP Calculus BC. After a quick review of limits, derivatives, basic integrals and u-substitution, the first half of the course teaches further techniques and applications of integration. The second part of the course centers on infinite sequences and series, followed by a brief introduction to differential equations.


Overall, students were dissatisfied with this section of MATH104. Some reported they “learned absolutely nothing from the class” and resorted to learning from tutors and the textbook instead. Many (up to two thirds of the class, by one reviewer’s estimate) chose not to attend lecture at all. Students thought the class was difficult, saying that they needed to attend every lecture to stay on top of new material. One person wrote that there was not enough time to complete the exams.


Most reviewers criticized Professor Crotty’s teaching ability. Lectures did not cover what was on the homework or text. Professor Crotty often went on tangents and much of what he taught was deemed irrelevant to the course material. One wrote that he “did not stimulate student interest”. One positive reviewer, however, called Professor Crotty “involved” and “passionate”, emailing students additional practice problems and painstakingly reviewing students’ midterms to explain point deductions and grant partial credit.


MATH104 fulfills basic requirements in all four undergraduate schools. The textbook used is Calculus by Stewart, 6th Edition.
